title: Why is there a scientific name and a common name for every animal? - Quora

response.answer_text: Some animals have many different common names, even in the same language. Famously, in American English, the cougar, mountain lion, and puma are all the same animal, and sometimes so is the panther — although a quite different felid is also known as the panther (and also as the leopard). And of course different languages very often have different common names for the same animal. But some animals do not have a common name. There are over a million species on this planet with scientific descriptions and names; most of them unknown to the vast majority of people; who would have a name for yet another species of tree-dwelling beetle in some remote corner of the Amazon? And of course there are many extinct species which have never been given a common name (indeed, it’s rare for an extinct species to have one). To get around the first problem — the confusing array of synonyms and shared names — scientific names (officially, they’re supposed to be treated as Latin words) are used. The cougar/puma may have half a dozen names just in American English, never mind other languages, but in scientific literature it — and nothing else — is always and only Puma concolor. Every species has, for scientific purposes, a unique name shared with no other species; it identifies exactly which species one is talking about and pigeonholes it in the nested hierarchy of life: domain: Eukarya, kingdom: Animalia, phylum, Chordata, class: Mammalia, order: Carnivora, family: Felidae, genus: Puma, species P. concolor.

The ‘scientific name’ is in the language of taxonomy - Latin - for the simple reason that it is a common language for scientists around the world, meaning less likelihood of misunderstandings through incorrect translations. It allows for the accurate pinpointing of each species. The common names are for the rest of us who simply prefer to call a dog a dog - the word for which varies in just about every language.
